description: Professional sensory template for IPA-style craft beers with focus on hop character and balance
expertNotes: IPAs are defined by hop-forward character balanced by malt backbone. West Coast = bitter/resinous; New England = juicy/hazy. Evaluate hop quality, freshness, and balance.

appearance.expertTips: West Coast IPAs are typically clear with white head. New England/Hazy IPAs should be turbid with persistent head. Golden color suggests fresh hops; brown tones may indicate oxidation.

aroma.prompt: Evaluate hop aromatic character and intensity
keyAttributes: Hop intensity (high is typical for IPA)
Hop character (citrus, pine, tropical, floral, dank)
aroma.expertTips: IPA aroma should be dominated by fresh hops. Citrus and tropical fruit aromas indicate modern hop varieties. Grassy or onion-like notes suggest old hops or poor storage.

frontMouth.prompt: Evaluate initial taste impact and carbonation
frontMouth.expertTips: IPAs should show immediate hop impact. Carbonation helps lift hop aromatics. Harsh bitterness (vs. clean bitterness) indicates poor hop quality or technique.

keyAttributes: Hop flavor complexity (resin, citrus, tropical, pine)
midRearMouth.expertTips: Balance is key - bitterness should be supported by malt sweetness. Hazy IPAs show softer bitterness with intense hop flavor. Dry-hopped character should dominate.

aftertaste.expertTips: IPA finish should be bitter but not astringent. Long finish (30-60 seconds) is typical. Clean, pleasant bitterness encourages another sip. Harsh or metallic finish indicates poor technique.

emotionalResponse.prompt: Capture the drinking experience and context
emotionalResponse.expertTips: IPAs appeal to craft enthusiasts seeking bold flavors. Session IPAs (<5% ABV) balance flavor with drinkability. Double/Imperial IPAs (7-10% ABV) are sipping beers.

benchmarkInsights: Well-balanced IPAs score 7-8/10 on moreishness. Extreme bitterness (9-10/10) often reduces repeat appeal to 4-6/10. Hazy IPAs show higher immediate appeal but may lack distinctiveness.
categoryTrends: Shift from bitter West Coast style to juicy/hazy New England style. Growing interest in low-ABV session IPAs and fruit-forward hop varieties. Freshness dating becoming standard.

styleTips.westCoast: Crystal clear, high bitterness (60-80 IBU), resinous/piney hops, dry finish
styleTips.newEngland: Hazy/turbid, softer bitterness (40-60 IBU), juicy tropical hops, fuller body
styleTips.session: Lower ABV (3-5%), balanced bitterness, high drinkability
styleTips.doubleIPA: High ABV (7-10%), intense hops, malt-forward, sipping beer
